Chapter 1: The Mirror's Arrival

We are introduced to the mirror in its past history in England many years before it was shipped off to America.
The mirror is boxed up and shipped to the United States.
The mirror is discovered by museum employees during a remodeling project.

Chapter 2: The Son

Jack, a teenager, becomes drawn to the mirror's alternate future.
Jack struggles to balance his present life with his desire for the alternate future.
Jack becomes increasingly isolated from his friends and family.
Jack's best friend tries to help him.

Chapter 3: The Son's Dream

Jack begins to have trouble distinguishing between the alternate reality and his own reality.
Jack's access to the mirror is cut off.
Jack reconnects with his friends and family.
Jack seeks therapy to work through his grief and move forward.
Jack sees a possible future with his deceased father and struggles to reconcile his desire for that future with his present life.

Chapter 4: The Mother

The mirror is sold to a married woman, Sarah, who lost her child.
Sarah becomes consumed by the alternate future the mirror shows her.
Sarah's relationship with her husband becomes strained.
Sarah's husband tries to intervene.

Chapter 5: The Mother's Dream

Sarah resists her husband's attempts to help, but she continues to be consumed by the mirror.
Sarah's husband finds a way to get rid of the mirror and break the hold it has on his wife.
Sarah seeks therapy to work through her grief and move forward.
Sarah's therapist helps her see the mirror in a different light.
Sarah sees a possible future with her deceased son and must confront the grief she has been suppressing.

Chapter 6: The Husband

The mirror is inherited by an elderly man, George, who lost his wife.
George becomes isolated and fixated on the alternate future the mirror shows him.
George struggles to let go of the alternate future and the memories it brings back.
George's relationship with his son and daughter becomes strained as his obsession with the mirror grows.

Chapter 7: The Husband's Dream

George's son tries to intervene, but George becomes angry and resentful.
George's daughter tries to help him let go of his obsession with the mirror and move on with his life.
George's daughter shatters the mirror to break the hold it has on her father.
George begins to focus on the good memories of his wife and finds solace in them.
George sees a possible future with his deceased wife and must learn to let go of the past and embrace the present.

EPILOGUE

We see the mirror broken into many pieces.
A new character finds these pieces, which appear to maintain the power of the mirror to show an alternate future.
The character looks into the mirror and sees...
Fade to end, leaving the reader wondering what could happen next.

What is the writing style of Charles Dickens

Charles Dickens is known for his literary style that is marked by a rich use of language, vivid descriptions, and colorful characters. His writing often features a blend of humor and sentimentality, and he is skilled at weaving intricate plotlines that are filled with suspense, mystery, and surprise.

Dickens was also known for his use of social commentary in his writing, often focusing on themes of poverty, injustice, and inequality. He frequently used his characters and stories to expose the harsh realities of life for the working-class people in Victorian England.

In terms of structure, Dickens was known for his use of serialized novels, where he would release his stories in installments over a period of time. This style of publication allowed him to build suspense and engage his readers, while also providing a regular income stream.

Overall, Dickens' writing style is characterized by its richness, complexity, and attention to detail, as well as its social commentary and ability to captivate readers with compelling stories and characters.

When we write this story, it will always be written in the writing style of Charles Dickens, meaning that the story should include the rich use of language, vivid descripting, and colorful characters, along with intricate plot lines that are filled with suspense, mystery and suprise. We want to captivate readers with compelling stories and characters. Additionallly, wherever possible, we want to have the plot advance through the use of dialog and description, rather than narrative and commentary.

As Susan sat in her therapist's office, she couldn't help but feel anxious about the fate of the mirror. She had finally been able to let go of her obsession with the alternate future that it showed her, but she couldn't shake the feeling that it was out there, still wreaking havoc on someone else's life.

"So, Susan," her therapist began, "it seems like you've made a lot of progress in accepting the loss of your son and moving forward."

"Yes, I have," Susan replied. "But I can't help but think about the mirror. I know I should just let it go, but I can't help but worry about who it might be affecting now."

Her therapist nodded sympathetically. "I understand your concern. But you have to trust that the mirror will find its way to where it needs to be, and that the person who inherits it will find a way to overcome its hold on them."

Susan nodded, but she still felt uneasy. Little did she know that the mirror had already found its way to San Francisco, where it now sat in the house of her ex-husband's daughter, Katherine.

"Hey, Dad," Katherine said as she answered the phone. "What's up?"

"I need you to do me a favor," her father said. "I have something that I need you to hold onto for a while."

"Okay," Katherine replied cautiously. "What is it?"

"It's a mirror," her father explained. "It belonged to your grandfather, and now I've inherited it. But I don't want it in my house. It's too painful of a reminder of your mother."

Katherine sighed. She had heard about the mirror from her mother, and she knew that it had caused a lot of pain and suffering for her family. But she couldn't help feeling curious about it.

"Fine, I'll take it," she said. "But I'm not making any promises about keeping it."

As Katherine hung up the phone, she couldn't help but wonder what kind of power the mirror held, and what kind of impact it would have on her life.

[TRANSITION]

After Sarah's husband finally removed the mirror from their house, he kept it hidden away in his garage, unsure of what to do with it. Eventually, he decided to give it to his daughter Katherine, who lived across the country in San Francisco. He hoped that the distance would keep the mirror from causing any further harm to their family.

[INTRODUCTION]

Katherine lived alone in a small apartment in the city, and it was there that the mirror took up residence. Her father George was staying with her for a few weeks, having come to visit her from the east coast. George was still grieving the loss of his wife, and the sight of the mirror brought back a flood of memories.

"I don't like that thing," George said, eyeing the mirror suspiciously as Katherine helped him unpack his bags. "It's bad luck, you know."

"Oh, don't be silly, Dad," Katherine replied with a chuckle. "It's just a mirror. And it's kind of cool, don't you think? Look at how ornate the frame is."

George grunted in response, not convinced. As the days went by, Katherine began to notice that her father was spending more and more time staring into the mirror. She tried to distract him with sightseeing and other activities, but he always found his way back to the mirror, lost in thought.

One night, as Katherine was cooking dinner, she heard her father talking to himself in the other room. She went to investigate and found him standing in front of the mirror, muttering under his breath.

"Dad, what are you doing?" she asked, concerned.

George turned to her, his eyes wild with emotion. "I saw her, Katie," he said, his voice trembling. "I saw your mother. She was there, in the mirror."
